Package ubc.cosc322

Class COSC322Test

java.lang.Object
ygraph.ai.smartfox.games.GamePlayer
ubc.cosc322.COSC322Test
public class COSC322Test
extends GamePlayer
An example illustrating how to implement a GamePlayer
Author:
Yong Gao (yong.gao@ubc.ca) Nov 23, 2020
COSC 322 Lab 01 (Warmup-1) In a text-based player,
  1. In the onLogin() method, print out the list of rooms on the server and join a room from the room list
  2. print out (in the method hanldeGameMessage(...) the message from the room.
To see how to get the room list and how to join a room, see API document of GameClient.java
COSC 322 Lab 02 (Warmup-2)
Turn this into a GUI-based Spectator by initialize an instance of BaseGameGUI.java and assign it to this.gamegui, and complete the following
  • Replace the code in your method onLogin() with the following two statements:
    userName = gameClient.getUserName();
    if(gamegui != null) {
    gamegui.setRoomInformation(gameClient.getRoomList());
    }
  • Add Implementation in the method handleGameMessage(...) to handle the two types game messages:
    1. GameMessage.GAME_STATE_BOARD (call BaseGameGui.setGameState(...) to set the game board)
    2. GameMessage.GAME_ACTION_MOVE (call BaseGameGui.updateGaemState(...) to update the game board)
      • In a game player, upon receiving this message about your opponent's move, you will also need to calculate your move and send your move to the server using the method GameClient.sendMoveMessage(...) (these are the core tasks of this project you will have to by the middle of March)
For a detailed description of the message format, see API document on GamePlayer.handleGameMessage(...)
If everything goes well, your program can be used as a spectator. To test your implementation, start two instances of HumanPlayer and have them join a game room, play a few moves, and then start your program and join the same room.

    • onLogin

      public void onLogin()
      Description copied from class: GamePlayer
      The method will be invoked by GameClient once the player has successfully logged onto the server. In this method, we usually find a room and join it.
      Specified by:
      onLogin in class GamePlayer

    • handleGameMessage

      public boolean handleGameMessage​(java.lang.String messageType, java.util.Map<java.lang.String,​java.lang.Object> msgDetails)
      Description copied from class: GamePlayer
      Call-back method upon receiving a message from the server
      Specified by:
      handleGameMessage in class GamePlayer
      Parameters:
      messageType - --- message type
      msgDetails - --- message details
      Returns:
      true unless something is wrong

      This method is called back by a GameClient whenever there is a game-related message from the server. For the COSC322 class, there are three types of messages as defined by the Strings: GameMessage.GAME_STATE_BOARD, GameMessage.GAME_ACTION_START, and GameMessage.GAME_ACTION_MOVE. The details of a message are included in the second argument "msgDetails" - a HashMap. The content of msgDetails for two types of messages is as follows.

      Type: GameMessage.GAME_STATE_BOARD
      Hash Key Object
      AmazonsGameMessage.GAME_STATE An ArrayList <Integer> encoding the game board
      Type: GameMessage.GAME_ACTION_START
      Hash Key Object
      AmazonsGameMessage.GAME_STATE An ArrayList <Integer> encoding the game board
      AmazonsGameMessage.PLAYER_BLACK A String for the user name of the player assigned to play the Black stone
      AmazonsGameMessage.PLAYER_WHITE A String for the user name of the player assigned to play the White stone
      Type: GameMessage.GAME_ACTION_MOVE
      Hash Key Object
      AmazonsGameMessage.QUEEN_POS_CURR An ArrayList <Integer> of size 2, for the current position (row, column) of the queen to be moved
      AmazonsGameMessage.QUEEN_POS_NEXT An ArrayList <Integer> of size 2, for the new position (row, column) for the queen to move to.
      AmazonsGameMessage.ARROW_POS An ArrayList <Integer> of size 2, for the position (row, column) of the arrow
